Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Story: I glanced at my phone and saw the message from Jamie—short, clipped, and clearly upset. My heart sank. She’d misunderstood my last text, and I knew I needed to call her right away to clear things up. That’s what friends do: talk things out, don’t let hurt feelings fester. But just as I reached for my phone, Mrs. Carter’s voice cut through the salon. She was glaring at her reflection, her voice rising, “This isn’t what I asked for at all!” The other stylists were already packing up, and the clock was ticking toward closing time. As her hairdresser, I was supposed to listen, stay calm, and fix things—no matter how tired or distracted I felt. My phone buzzed again in my pocket, Jamie’s name lighting up the screen. I could feel the pressure mounting, torn between the friend who needed reassurance and the client demanding my full attention. My hands trembled slightly as I tried to decide who needed me more in this moment, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in from all sides.
